lookup_hed: How to cast a tactical vote
stance_label: Do you support Theresa May’s plans for Brexit?
stance_remain: No! Brits deserve a better deal.
practical_hed: Seats where tactical voting can realistically make a difference
practical_footnote: Data: The UK Electoral Commission, the BBC, Chris Hanretty (University of East Anglia), Quartz analysis
ideal_hed: Hypothetical best cases for tactical voters
ideal_footnote: Data: The UK Electoral Commission, Quartz analysis
section_1: It is a time of political upheaval in much of the world. But none more so than in the UK, which is going for a second general election in just over two years.

The UK surprised the world by voting to leave the EU in June last year. Soon after that Theresa May took over the prime ministership from her predecessor David Cameron. According to the rules, she could’ve continued to govern the country until 2020, but she has taken a gamble by calling for a general election. That’s because the latest polls suggest that, on June 8, Brits would vote to give her Conservative party an even bigger majority than it has currently.

Typically campaigns for general elections start many years in advance. Instead, this time May’s “snap” election gives the country’s many political parties only weeks to organise, campaign, and sway voters. What perhaps makes life easier for them is that the election is, in effect, about only one thing: Brexit.

The upshot is that voters really have only one of two choices. Give May’s right-leaning party a bigger majority to ensure Brexit happens on her terms. Or vote for the left-leaning opposition parties, who may be fractured in what they are promising, but at least they all oppose giving May a blank check.

Current polls suggest a surge in the Conservative vote since the 2015 general election. And, yet, whether you are for May’s Brexit or against, tactical voting could significantly change the outcome of the election. Quartz’s analysis below shows which seats could realistically make the difference.
section_2: In making the calculation, we’ve overlaid data from the 2015 general elections and  the 2016 Brexit referendum. The realistic chances are determined by whether a particular seat has enough of a chance to swing from “leave” to “remain” (or vice-versa) and whether that swing could enable a large enough voter base to cast a tactical vote.

Of course, the left-leaning parties—Labour, Liberal Democrats, Scottish Nationalist Party, and Green—have differences among them on what they think about Brexit. But tactical voting could work because they are unified in their opposition to Theresa May’s Brexit.

On the opposite site, May has the upper hand of gaining from a large proportion of UK Independence Party voters. Those who chose the far-right party in 2015 did so mainly to leave the EU, but since the referendum the party has lost steam and it could mean the voters would tactically vote for May.
There is a chance for a greater swing. Such a hypothetical best-case scenario would make a much larger difference to the outcome of the election, as can be seen in the maps below.
section_3: Data used in this story comes from three sources. First, we use official tallies of the 2015 general election results to understand the balance of power between the parties. Second, we use official tallies of the Brexit referendum gathered by the BBC from the small number of constituencies that publish them. Third, for those seats that didn’t publish official referendum tallies, we use estimates produced by Chris Hanretty of the University of East Anglia.

We identify as a swing seat any constituency where tactical voting could bring the margin between voters on different sides of the leave/remain issue to less than 5%. This is an arbitrary threshold and it’s entirely possible the real votes will swing by much more or much less.

When projecting “ideal” outcomes we assume that every voter on just one side of the Brexit divide will engage in tactical voting. That, of course, is extremely unlikely, but it helps us understand the range of possible outcomes for the 2017 election. We do not account for the case where voters on one side might engage in reverse tactical voting, intentionally splitting their vote to undermine their party’s position on Brexit.
Similarly, when looking at Brexit referendum results, we’ve assumed that a “swing seat” is any place where the gap between leave and remain voters was at most 5%.
Parties included in the “other” category are the Democratic Unionist Party, Plaid Cymru, the Social Democratic and Labor Party, Sinn Fein, and the Ulster Unionist Party.
None of the data described here should be construed as a prediction of future election results.
